resources.string: Please enter a non-zero positive value

The Green Food Challenge application aims to help people collectively reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Metro Vancouver.

 Since 2011 Vancouver has spearheaded the Greenest CIty Action Plan with the goal of becoming the greenest city in the world by 2020. Of the plan’s 10 specific goals, one is to reduce its carbon footprint by 33% compared to 2006 levels.

\tA carbon footprint is the amount of carbon dioxide and other carbon compounds produced to directly or indirectly support the human activities of a person or group. This footprint is most often described in CO2e (CO2 equivalents) and measured in kilograms or tonnes. In 2015, regional emissions in Metro Vancouver were projected to be 14.9 million tonnes of CO2e, or between 6 and 8 tonnes per person. It is generally estimated that global emissions must be reduced to approximately 2 tonnes per capita by 2050.\n

\tThere are many CO2e contributors to our carbon footprint, including transportation and buildings (heating, power, etc.). Many Municipalities, including Vancouver, are currently undertaking measures to reduce their footprints in ways such as promoting public transit over personal vehicles, or changing heating systems from natural gas to hydroelectric.\n

\tFood is generally under-reported as a source of CO2e. For instance in Europe, agriculture contributes to 10% of the carbon footprint. In particular, livestock such as sheep and cows produce methane and contribute more to CO2e than any other animals. According to the European Commission, about 85% of methane emissions come from livestock digestion.\n Certain foods take more CO2e to produce than others. The table below shows relative CO2e costs for various types of food.\n

\tThis application was developed with the goal of raising awareness and promoting positive behaviour change by running the Green Food Challenge. In this challenge people will track their meals daily and record the quantity of meat and alternatives they are consuming. With this data, participants will be able to see what their projected yearly carbon ‘foodprint’ will be, based on a weekly average of their meals. Through the recommendations tab users will receive suggestions on how to make their diet more ‘green’, and see how many tonnes of CO2e that they, and the city of Vancouver, could save by making these adjustments. By encouraging CO2e-friendly meals and showing what a difference they could make, it is hoped that participants learn to sustainably change their eating habits towards a lighter footprint, bringing us closer to being the greenest city in the world.\n
Your 7 Day Meal Consumption in grams
